awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: The Search for Novel Superconductors in Moire Flat Bands
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: This project will investigate novel unconventional superconductors based on atomically thin materials stacked with a twisted angle between them. When two atomic layers with similar atomic structure meet each other, a larger scale quasi periodic structure called a moire pattern forms. Electronic structure of these interfacial structure can be engineered by adjusting the twisting angle. When the electron energy distribution is narrow, strong correlation between them appear, which can in turn drive the system to be a dissipationless superconducting state. Experimental and theoretical research, in conjunction with the predictive powers of advanced computational methods, will be developed to achieve a better understanding of the physical mechanisms at work and will contribute to the ability to design superconducting materials with higher transition temperatures. The project will provide fundamental understanding of the materials properties and phenomena that underpin superconducting electronic device applications in low energy electronics, quantum sensing, and more importantly quantum computing applications. A new generation of scientists will be trained who are deeply involved in both experimental and theoretical/modeling research with complimentary expertise.

Technical Description: The moire heterostructure engineering of 2-dimensional (2D) van der Waals (vdW) materials leads to quantum heterostructures. Utilizing recently demonstrated twisted vdW heteroepitaxy, the investigators will construct vdW homo/hetero structures to realize correlated electronic states that appear in the moire flat bands. With inputs from theory and mathematical modeling of multiscale electronic structure, the project will experimentally investigate multilayer 2D superconducting systems with unusual properties, such as gate tunable transition temperature and non-conventional pairing symmetries. Various material platforms will be explored including twisted double bilayer graphene, twisted trilayer graphene and twisted homo- and hetetro-structures based on transition metal dichalcogenides. Theoretical guidance will be an indispensable part of this study since there are a variety of choices for material platforms and twist angle which cannot be covered by experiment alone without targeted modeling guide. Unconventional superconductivity can also lead into the development and discovery of topological superconductors, which can be utilized for quantum computing. The qubits realized in topological superconducting systems hold promise for fault-tolerant quantum computation, thanks to the topological nature of the underlying quantum states.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, "The Search for Novel Superconductors in Moire Atomic Layers," we develop new experimental and theoretical tools to study novel unconventional superconductors in twisted stacked atomically thin materials.

The Intellectual Merit of this study is to establish our understanding of correlated physical phenomena in moire superlattices. When two atomic layers with similar atomic structure are combined, a larger scale quasi-periodic lattice structure appears. This moire heterostructure engineering of 2-dimensional (2D) van der Waals (vdW) materials provides a new quantum materials platform. In this project, we expanded twisted bilayer systems to consecutively-twisted trilayer graphene material platforms, in which the two moire superlattices co-exist and competes with each other, giving rise to novel moire of moire superlattices with a plethora of new lattice periodicities and novel quantum phenomena. Different material platforms including twisted bilayer graphene, twisted double bilayer graphene and twisted trilayer graphene, and twisted homo- and hetetrostructures based on transition metal dichalcogenides have been studied. We discovered a new set of quantum phenomena including the tunable inter-moire Hofstadter butterfly and moire of moire superconductivity and correlated insulator states at extremely low carrier density on the order of 10-10 cm-2. We developed an understanding of how the electronic structure of tTLG can be carefully engineered by twist angle, local atomic strain and electrostatic gating.  Experimental and theoretical research, combined with the predictive power of advanced computational methods, was developed to achieve a better understanding of the physical mechanisms at work.

For new experimental tools to understand moire of moire systems, we have developed protocols to consistently fabricate state-of-the-art twisted trilayer graphene material platforms with precise control over each twist angle. This allows us to demonstrate correlated insulator states and the signature of superconductivity with unprecedently low carrier density, and study of the interplay between the two moire superlattices and their mutual role in determining the emergent quantum phenomena. We have also developed device fabrication protocols of atomically-flat local nano-gating without introducing atomic-strain to the moire systems. This allowed us to study mesoscopic quantum transport in quantum devices made of moire and moire of moire superlattices, in which electrons are electrostatically manipulated and confined to probe the microscopic underlying physics and demonstrate novel device functionality. We demonstrate collimation of ballistic electron flow in tBLG via gate-defined moire barriers,  and provide new insights in electron transport in moire superlattices.

Theoretical guidance provided a deep understanding of the variety of choices for material platforms and twist angles that cannot be covered by experiment alone without targeted modeling guidance. We have developed a theoretical/computational model for the mechanical and electronic properties of general 2D heterostructures. Consecutively twisted graphene is the first experimentally studied heterostructure to require the full power of this configuration space. formulation since the configuration space is four-dimensional.

The project has provided a fundamental understanding of the material properties and phenomena that underlie superconducting electronic device applications.  Unconventional superconductivity can lead to the design and discovery of topological superconductors that can be used for quantum computing

Broader Impact: The PIs have closely integrated the education and outreach program with research at the frontier of low-dimensional materials systems. The PIs trained graduate and undergraduate students in quantum matter research at the interface of experimental and theoretical science. The PIs organized an annual two-day math camp for junior high and high school students in the University of Minnesota Talented Youth Mathematics Program.
